Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba

Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart

Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.

Character 8

Name: Kazuma Asogi

Testimony 2 from Sandwich: He mentions that Gossip couldn't wait to go see what happened. So, Gossip was eager to get to the scene, possibly after the crime had occurred.

Testimony 3 from Gossip again: He ran into the room and saw the Reaper with a gun standing over the body. So, the crime was already completed when he arrived, and the Reaper was still present.

Testimony 4 from Gossip: He slipped over and got blood on his hand, then wiped it off on the floor. This suggests that there was blood present at the scene, possibly from the victim, Gregson.

Testimony 5 from Venus: She was scared and ran off to find a copper. So, after the crime, she fled to get help.

Now, looking at the evidence related to these testimonies. Evidence 7 is the Revolver, which was the murder weapon. Evidence 5 is the Red Hairpiece found at the scene, which presumably belonged to Inspector Gregson.

Evidence 6 is the Candelabrum with a blown-off candle, suggesting that there was a disturbance, possibly from an explosion or a struggle.

Evidence 8 is the Policeman Figurine, which when twisted, releases a key-like shaft. This might be a clue, but not directly contradictory.

Evidence 9 is the Framed Photograph of Mrs. Vigil, found on a desk. That seems unrelated to the crime scene.

Evidence 13 is the Noticeboard with a bloody handprint. Testimony 4 mentions Gossip got blood on his hand, so this evidence supports that.

Evidence 12 is the Crime Scene Floor Plan, which would show the layout where the crime happened.

Now, considering the testimonies and the evidence, the key point is the timing. Testimony 1 says it was less than a minute after the Reaper went in that they heard a bang. So, the crime happened very quickly. The evidence related to this would be the Revolver (Evidence 7) and the Candelabrum (Evidence 6). 

If the crime happened in less than a minute, the Reaper would have had minimal time to act. However, Testimony 3 says that when Gossip entered the room, the Reaper was still standing over the body with a gun. That suggests that the crime wasn't just a quick act but that the Reaper had time to commit the murder and perhaps be in the room when Gossip arrived.

Wait, but if it happened so quickly, maybe the Reaper didn't have time to be standing over the body. Or perhaps the evidence contradicts the testimony.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 7 (Revolver) and Evidence 6 (Candelabrum). If the crime was a quick shooting, the Revolver would be the weapon. But the Candelabrum having a blown-off candle might suggest that there was an explosion or something else, which might not align with a quick shooting.

Wait, but the Candelabrum's candle being blown off could be from the explosion of the Venus Firecracker (Evidence 14). The firecracker is described as going off like a gunshot. So, maybe the Reaper used the firecracker to create a distraction or cause a noise, which would fit with the bang heard by Venus.

But then, the Revolver is the actual murder weapon. So, the timing is that the Reaper went in, then less than a minute later, there was a bang (the firecracker) and then the revolver shot.

Wait, but the testimonies say that the big bang was after the Reaper went in. So, the bang could be from the firecracker, not the revolver. But the revolver is the murder weapon, so the shot would be the actual murder.

Wait, but if the crime happened in less than a minute, the Reaper would have fired the revolver quickly, but the firecracker might have been a distraction before the shot.

Hmm, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 1 (bang less than a minute after entering) and Evidence 7 (Revolver) and Evidence 14 (Firecracker). But I'm not sure.

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 3, Gossip saw the Reaper standing over the body with a gun. So, the Reaper had time to commit the murder. But if the crime happened in less than a minute, the Reaper wouldn't have had time to stand over the body unless he was already there when Gossip arrived, which he was.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between the timing. If the crime happened so quickly, the Reaper wouldn't have had time to stand over the body unless he was already there. But if the crime took longer, then the timing in Testimony 1 might not match.

Alternatively, looking at the autopsy report (Evidence 11): It says death was instant from a bullet at close range. So, the crime was quick, supporting Testimony 1. But the fact that the Reaper was still standing over the body (Testimony 3) suggests that he was present after the shooting, which could mean the crime took a bit longer, but the autopsy says it was instant.

Wait, that might be a contradiction. If the death was instant, the Reaper wouldn't have had time to stand over the body unless he was already there when the shooting happened.

Alternatively, perhaps the timing of the bang is from the firecracker, not the revolver. So, the Reaper triggered the firecracker (bang) and then shot Gregson. But that would mean two sounds, but Venus only mentions one big bang.

Wait, but in Testimony 1, Venus says they heard a big bang less than a minute after the Reaper went in. So, that's the only bang. Then, the revolver shot would have been the murder, but if it's a gunshot, that would be another sound. But perhaps the firecracker was used to create the bang, and then the revolver was used to kill Gregson, but that would mean two sounds, which isn't mentioned.

Alternatively, perhaps the firecracker was used to distract or create a noise, but the actual murder was done quickly, so the only bang was from the firecracker, and the revolver shot was instantaneous, so no additional sound.

Hmm, I'm getting a bit confused. Maybe I should look for a more direct contradiction.

Looking back, Testimony 3 says the Reaper was standing over the body with a gun. So, he was present after the shooting. But if the crime happened so quickly (Testimony 1), the Reaper wouldn't have had time to stand over the body unless he was already there when the shooting occurred.

Wait, but the crime happened when the Reaper entered the room. So, if he entered, shot Gregson instantly, and then stood over him, that would mean the crime took a bit longer, contradicting the autopsy report which says death was instant.

Alternatively, the autopsy says it was instant, so the Reaper didn't have time to stand over the body, but Testimony 3 says he did. That's a contradiction.

So, the evidence that says death was instant (Evidence 11) contradicts Testimony 3, which says the Reaper was standing over the body.

Therefore, the evidence (Evidence 11) and testimony (Testimony 3) contradict each other.
</think>
